To reproduce:

- Add a JAR to a project
- Open the .classpath
- Go into the line which contains the JAR
- Add: sourcepath="/WORKSPACE/no/such/archive"
- Click on an exception trace

Eclipse will now take a timeout (~10s) and then display this message: "Error logged from JDT Debug UI: Unable to access archive D:\workspace\no\such\archive"

In the error log, you can see:

org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Unable to access archive D:\workspace\no\such\archive
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.containers.AbstractSourceContainer.abort(AbstractSourceContainer.java:44)
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.containers.ExternalArchiveSourceContainer.getArchive(ExternalArchiveSourceContainer.java:201)
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.containers.ExternalArchiveSourceContainer.findSourceElements(ExternalArchiveSourceContainer.java:78)
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.containers.CompositeSourceContainer.findSourceElements(CompositeSourceContainer.java:78)
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.containers.CompositeSourceContainer.findSourceElements(CompositeSourceContainer.java:45)
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.AbstractSourceLookupParticipant.findSourceElements(AbstractSourceLookupParticipant.java:67)
	at org.eclipse.debug.core.sourcelookup.AbstractSourceLookupDirector$SourceLookupQuery.run(AbstractSourceLookupDirector.java:136)

Please add two fixes:

1. Add the name of the project and the JAR to the error message so a user can find the cause of the problem faster.
2. Possibly ignore non-existing source archives.

Afterwards, an error for the refactoring guys must be created, because the source of my problems was a rename of a project which contained the source of the JAR. It seems source classpaths are not considered during the refactoring "Rename".
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 148872 ***
